unnormalised: ## Yoga Practices: Beyond the Asanas, What Works for You?
normalised: ## Yoga Practices: Beyond the Asanas, What Works for You?

unnormalised: Okay, so we all know about Yoga being amazing for stress relief and flexibility. But honestly, sometimes I get overwhelmed with all the different types – Ashtanga, Hatha, Vinyasa…it’s a lot!
normalised: Okay, so we all know about Yoga being amazing for stress relief and flexibility. But honestly, sometimes I get overwhelmed with all the different types – Ashtanga, Hatha, Vinyasa…it’s a lot!

unnormalised: As someone who's been practicing yoga off and on for the last 5 years (mostly near my home in Andheri, Mumbai), I've realized it's not just about perfecting the poses. It's about finding what *resonates* with you.
normalised: As someone who's been practicing yoga off and on for the last five years (mostly near my home in Andheri, Mumbai), I've realized it's not just about perfecting the poses. It's about finding what *resonates* with you.

unnormalised: For example, I find that starting my day with even 15 minutes of Surya Namaskar really sets a positive tone. And pranayama (breathing exercises) like Kapalabhati are a game changer when I'm feeling anxious. Dr. Sharma at the local Arogya clinic recommended Nadi Shodhana for calming my mind, and it actually works!
normalised: For example, I find that starting my day with even fifteen minutes of Surya Namaskar really sets a positive tone. And pranayama (breathing exercises) like Kapalabhati are a game changer when I'm feeling anxious. unnormalised: I've tried those intense Bikram yoga classes (Rs. 500 a session!), but honestly, they leave me feeling drained. I prefer something more restorative, like Yin yoga, which I can do at home in my 100 sq ft living room.
normalised: I've tried those intense Bikram yoga classes (rupee five hundred a session!), but honestly, they leave me feeling drained. I prefer something more restorative, like Yin yoga, which I can do at home in my one hundred square feet living room.

unnormalised: Has anyone else had similar experiences? What are your go-to yoga practices? Any tips for beginners who are feeling a bit lost in the world of Yoga? Do you prefer studios or practicing at home? Share your thoughts – maybe we can all learn something new! Even travelling to places like Rishikesh to learn yoga from the source may be a nice choice!
